entry.title: The Mackey Problem
entry.content:
Introduction

It all started when John Mackey, who teaches the infamous first-year 15-151 Mathematical Foundations for Computer Science course (better known as Concepts) at CMU, casually posed the following puzzle at the end of one of his lectures:

“Is the set of injections \(\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}} ightarrow \mathbb{R}\) uncountable?”

It wasn’t necessarily framed as a challenge—more of a throwaway brainteaser. But my classmate Pietro and I couldn’t resist poking at it further. A few days later, we finally pinned down a clean argument showing that the set is indeed uncountable.

What follows is our proof, largely motivated by Cantor’s classic diagonalization ideas, that we hope does justice to Mackey’s provocative question.

Solution to The Mackey Problem

Setup

We want to prove the set of injections \(\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}} ightarrow \mathbb{R}\) is uncountable. By Cantor’s Diagonalization argument, \(\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}\) is uncountable. Thus, we construct an injection \(g:\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}} ightarrow \{f \mid f: \{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}} ightarrow \mathbb{R} ext{ and } f ext{ is injective}\}\). Define \(g\) via:

\[g(b) = f_{b}\]

where each \(f_b: \{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}} ightarrow \mathbb{R}\) is defined via

\[f_{b}(b') = \sum{i\in\mathbb{N}} rac{b_i'(b_i + 1)}{10^{i+1}}\]

Note for the curious reader that for the \(i\)th digits \(b_i\) and \(b_i'\) of the infinite binary strings \(b\) and \(b'\),

\[b_i'(b_i + 1) = egin{cases} 0 & ext{if } b_i' = 0, \ 1 & ext{if } b_i = 0 ext{ and } b_i' = 1, \ 2 & ext{if } b_i = 1 ext{ and } b_i' = 1. \end{cases}\]

Intuition into g

First, we provide an example to illustrate how \(g\) maps binary strings to injections from binary strings to real numbers.

Consider the following values:

\[ egin{align*} b &= 11010110\ b' &= 01101101\ \end{align*}\]

Then by the construction of \(g(b) = f_b\),

\[ egin{align*} f_b(b') =.02101201 \end{align*}\]

Observe that whenever \(b'\) has a \(0\) at index \(i\), the \(i\)th decimal place of \(f_b(b')\) will always be \(0\). When \(b'\) has a \(1\) at index \(i\), the \(i\)th decimal place of \(f_b(b')\) will be \(1\) if \(b_i = 0\) and \(2\) if \(b_i = 1\). We prove this mapping is injective below.

We show \(f_b\) is well-defined

Note we have defined \(f_b\) generally as one unique value, so it satisfies totality and uniqueness. To demonstrate the existence of \(f_b\), consider an infinite binary string \(b'\). Observe that:

\[ egin{align*} & b' \in \{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}, \ \implies \quad & b_i' \in \{0,1\} \quad ext{for all } i \in \mathbb{N}, \ \implies \quad & f_b(b') = \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{b_i'(b_i + 1)}{10^{i+1}} \in \mathbb{R}, \end{align*}\]

since \(b_i', b_i, 10^{i+1} \in \mathbb{R}\) and \(\mathbb{R}\) is closed under addition, multiplication, and division. Therefore, \(f_b\) satisfies existence. Because \(f_b\) satisfies existence, uniqueness and totality, it is well-defined.

We show \(f_b\) is injective

We show \(f_b\) is injective by the contrapositive.

Suppose \(b_1', b_2' \in \{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}\) such that \(b_1' eq b_2'\). Therefore, there exists a least index \(j \in \mathbb{N}\)where the digits of \(b_1'\) and \(b_2'\) differ. Without loss of generality, assume \((b_1')_j = 1\) and \((b_2')_j = 0\). Then, we have

\[ egin{align*} & (b_1')_j(b_j + 1) = 1 \cdot (b_j + 1) \enspace ext{ and }\enspace (b_2')_j(b_j + 1) = 0 \cdot (b_j + 1), \ \implies \quad & (b_1')_j(b_j + 1) \in \{1,2\} \enspace ext{ and }\enspace (b_2')_j(b_j + 1) = 0, \ \implies \quad & (b_1')_j(b_j + 1) eq (b_2')_j(b_j + 1) \end{align*}\]

Let \(n_1, n_2 \in \{0,1,2\}^{\mathbb{N}}\) such that \((n_1)_i = (b_1')_i(b_i + 1)\) and \((n_2)_i = (b_2')_i(b_i + 1)\) for all \(i \in \mathbb{N}\). Since \((b_1')_j(b_j + 1) eq (b_2')_j(b_j + 1)\) it follows that \((n_1)_j eq(n_2)_j\), so \(n_1 eq n_2\). Invoking Lemma A found in the appendix, we have

\[ egin{align*} &\sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{(b'_1)_i(b_i + 1)}{10^{i+1}} eq \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{(b'_2)_i(b_i + 1)}{10^{i+1}} \end{align*}\]

It follows that \(f_b(b_1') eq f_b(b_2')\), and thus that \(f_b\) is injective.

We show \(g\) is well-defined

Note we have defined \(g\) generally as one unique value, so it satisfies totality and uniqueness. We show existence for \(g\).

Let \(b \in \{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}\), thus \(g(b) = f_b\). Because \(f_b\) is defined as a function from \(\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}\) to \(\mathbb{R}\) and it has been shown to be injective, it follows that \(g(b) = f_b\) is in the set \(\{f \mid f: \{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}} ightarrow \mathbb{R} ext{ and } f ext{ is injective}\}\), hence \(g\) satisfies existence.

Because $g$ satisfies existence, uniqueness, and totality, it is well-defined.

Finally, we show $g$ is injective

We show the contrapositive, or that for all binary strings \(b_1\) and \(b_2\), \(b_1 eq b_2 \implies g(b_1) eq g(b_2)\).

Suppose \(b_1, b_2 \in \{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}\) such that \(b_1 eq b_2\). Then we have \(g(b_1) = f_{b_1}\) and \(g(b_2) = f_{b_2}\). To show \(g(b_1) eq g(b_2)\), we must show \(f_{b_1} eq f_{b_2}\). It suffices to show they have different outputs for some input.

Consider the binary string \(b' = \{1\}^{\mathbb{N}} = 111111\dots\), so for all \(i \in \mathbb{N}$, $b_i' = 1\). We show this binary string produces different outputs for \(f_{b_1} ext { and } f_{b_2}\). Observe that:

\[f_{b_1}(b') = f_{b_1}(\{1\}^{\mathbb{N}}) = \sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}} rac{b_i'((b_1)_i + 1)}{10^{i+1}} = \sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}} rac{1\cdot((b_1)_i + 1)}{10^{i+1}}\] \[f_{b_2}(b') = f_{b_2}(\{1\}^{\mathbb{N}}) = \sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}} rac{b_i'((b_2)_i + 1)}{10^{i+1}} = \sum_{i\in\mathbb{N}} rac{1\cdot((b_2)_i + 1)}{10^{i+1}}\]

Note because \(b_1 eq b_2\), there exists a least index \(j \in \mathbb{N}\) where the digits of \(b_1\) and \(b_2\) differ. Without loss of generality, assume \((b_1)_j = 1\) and \((b_2)_j = 0\). Then we have

\[ egin{align*} (b_1)_j + 1 = 2 \enspace ext{ and }\enspace (b_2)_j + 1 = 1 \implies (b_1)_j + 1 eq (b_2)_j + 1 \end{align*}\]

Let \(n_1, n_2 \in \{0,1,2\}^{\mathbb{N}}\) such that \((n_1)_i = (b_1)_i + 1\) and \((n_2)_i = (b_2)_i + 1\) for all \(i \in \mathbb{N}\). Since \((b_1)_j + 1 eq (b_2)_j + 1\) it follows that \((n_1)_j eq(n_2)_j\), so \(n_1 eq n_2\). Invoking Lemma A found in the appendix, we have

\[ egin{align*} &\sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{(b_1)_i + 1}{10^{i+1}} eq \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{(b_2)_i + 1}{10^{i+1}} \end{align*}\]

It follows that \(f_{b_1}(b') eq f_{b_2}(b')\), and because the functions differ in output for \(b'\), they are not the same function, or \(f_{b_1} eq f_{b_2}\). Hence \(g(b_1) eq g(b_2)\), so \(g\) is injective.

Conclusion

Since \(g\) is an injective function from the uncountable set \(\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}\) to the set of injections \(\{f \mid f: \{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}} ightarrow \mathbb{R}\}\), the latter set is also uncountable.

Appendix

Lemma A

Let \(n_1, n_2 \in \{0,1,2\}^{\mathbb{N}}\) with \(n_1 eq n_2\). We prove that

\[ egin{align*} \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{(n_1)_i}{10^{i+1}} eq \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{(n_2)_i}{10^{i+1}}. \end{align*}\]

Since \(n_1 eq n_2\), there exists a least index \(j \in \mathbb{N}\) where \((n_1)_j eq (n_2)_j\). Without loss of generality, assume \((n_1)_j < (n_2)_j\). Then, for all \(i < j\), \((n_1)_i = (n_2)_i\), implying

\[ egin{align*} \sum_{i=0}^{j-1} rac{(n_1)_i}{10^{i+1}} = \sum_{i=0}^{j-1} rac{(n_2)_i}{10^{i+1}}. \end{align*}\]

We focus on the sums from index \(j\) onward, so it suffices to show:

\[ egin{align*} \sum_{i=j}^{\infty} rac{(n_1)_i}{10^{i+1}} eq \sum_{i=j}^{\infty} rac{(n_2)_i}{10^{i+1}}. \end{align*}\]

For \(i \geq j+1\), setting \((n_1)_i = 2\) maximizes \(\sum_{i=j+1}^{\infty} rac{(n_1)_i}{10^{i+1}}\). This sum forms an infinite geometric series with the first term \(a = rac{2}{10^{j+2}}\) and common ratio \(r = rac{1}{10}\).

The sum of this series is given by

\[ rac{a}{1-r} = rac{ rac{2}{10^{j+2}}}{1- rac{1}{10}} = rac{2}{9 \cdot 10^{j+1}}.\]

Note \( rac{2}{9 \cdot 10^{j+1}} < rac{1}{10^{j+1}}\). Similarly, the minimum value of \(\sum_{i=j+1}^{\infty} rac{(n_2)_i}{10^{i+1}}\) is \(0\), occurring when \((n_2)_i = 0\) for \(i \geq j+1\). Thus,

\[ egin{align*} &(n_1)_j < (n_2)_j \ \implies&(n_1)_j + 1 \leq (n_2)_j &n_1, n_2 \in \{0,1,2\}^{\mathbb{N}}\ \implies& rac{(n_1)_j}{10^{j+1}} + rac{1}{10^{j+1}} \leq rac{(n_2)_j}{10^{j+1}}\ \implies& rac{(n_1)_j}{10^{j+1}} + \sum_{i=j+1}^{\infty} rac{(n_1)_i}{10^{i+1}} < rac{(n_2)_j}{10^{j+1}} &\sum_{i=j+1}^{\infty} rac{(n_1)_i}{10^{i+1}} \leq rac{2}{9 \cdot 10^{j+1}} < rac{1}{10^{j+1}}\ \implies& rac{(n_1)_j}{10^{j+1}} + \sum_{i=j+1}^{\infty} rac{(n_1)_i}{10^{i+1}} < rac{(n_2)_j}{10^{j+1}} + \sum_{i=j+1}^{\infty} rac{(n_2)_i}{10^{i+1}} &\sum_{i=j+1}^{\infty} rac{(n_2)_i}{10^{i+1}} \geq 0\ \end{align*}\]

Hence,

\[ egin{align*} \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{(n_1)_i}{10^{i+1}} < \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{(n_2)_i}{10^{i+1}} \implies \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{(n_1)_i}{10^{i+1}} eq \sum_{i \in \mathbb{N}} rac{(n_2)_i}{10^{i+1}}. \end{align*}\]
entry.summary: Prove that the set of injections from the set of infinite binary sequences to the real numbers is uncountable.
